title: Lost at Night
summary: Light pollution is when light produced by humans spreads into the sky, making it harder to see the natural beauty of the sky and disrupting wildlife. Lost at Night helps map light pollution to monitor it and see how it affects organisms across the world.
people: teams of one or two students
skills:
• Human impact on Earth systems
  • Knowledge about pollution and its impact on natural life
instructions:
1. This project requires you to match images of cities taken from NASA’s International Space Station to help identify where they are, helping scientists be able to understand which areas in the world need to decrease their light pollution. Go to https://lostatnight.org/ and click on “Go to project”.
  2. Click through the four tutorial panels. When you are ready, click the X button in the top, right corner OR the “Let’s start button” on the fourth panel.
  3. You will then see a problem image, which is what scientists need help identifying.
  4. Scroll through the choices of images from A-L at the top of the screen and choose the image that is closest to the problem image in brightness of the lights. When you click an image, it will pop up next to the problem image so that you can compare up close.
  5. Once you are sure that it is as close as possible, select that image, and write down the location you identified, and sketch the image on your worksheet If none of the images seem to be identical to the problem image, click “None of these”, and instead sketch the problem image on your worksheet.
  6. Click the blue button beneath the image that says “Confirm [chosen letter]”.
  7. Repeat this image matching process until you have identified a total of 15 different locations (you can do more if you’d like).
  8. If you aren’t sure, ask someone near you or your teacher to help decide.
  9. When you are done, exit out of the tab.
extension: Click on the menu button (the three lines in the upper, left corner of the screen), and then click on where it says “Results”. You can choose a date (try today’s date, or your birthday this year!) to see how many people across the world contributed to the project on that day. Rotate the earth around. Do you recognize any locations that you identified today?
videodes: Learn about the causes of light pollution and why it's harmful to our environment
video2des: See how light pollution affects our view of the Milky Way

title: AstroQuest
summary: AstroQuest is a project where citizen scientists can help Australian astronomers on their research. Their computers are trained with algorithms to identify where galaxies are, so they need your help to increase the accuracy of these computers.
people: teams of one or two students
skills: • Knowledge about galaxies, the Universe, and its stars
instructions:
1. Go to https://astroquest.net.au and login using the information provided by your teacher. If they don’t have a login, you can create a new account.
  2. Watch the 5 minute tutorial as a class, or by yourself.
  3. Once you have an account, head to the “Quests” page and click “Begin Quest”.
  4. The screen will show a picture of a galaxy, and there will be an overlay on top of the galaxy that is generated by the computer. You can adjust this using the “Opacity” bar.
  5. You can also toggle between the different “Light Channels”, which together make up the full image.
  6. Go through the list on the left to make sure that the computer isn’t missing anything. If you think the computer is completely accurate, click “Yes”. If not, click “No”.
  7. If you clicked “No”, it will take you to a screen where you can edit the computer’s image. Use the pencil tool to shade in areas of the galaxy that the computer missed and use the star tool to mark any stars that are overlapping on the main galaxy in the image. Once you are done, click “Save”.
  8. After you submit, you can read some information about the galaxy you just identified to learn more about its history and composition! Click “Next Galaxy” to classify another galaxy.
  9. When you are done, exit out of the tab.
extension: Search up the Milky Way galaxy. What's so special about this galaxy?
videodes: Learn about the Milky Way and other galaxies
video2des: In-depth video about the Milky Way

title: Smoke Hunting
summary: The Carnegie Mellon University CREATE Lab is using Artificial Intelligence (AI) to label smoke emissions across the world. This project’s goal is to analyze air pollution. By participating in this Smoke Hunting project, you are helping their AI system improve its accuracy.
people: teams of one or two students
skills:
• Human impact on Earth systems
  • Knowledge about pollution and its impact on natural life
instructions:
1. Go to https://smoke.createlab.org/https://smoke.createlab.org/ and click the “Learn More” button.
  2. Scroll through the images and text to learn about the difference between smoke and steam. This difference is important, because you will be selecting images that have smoke.
  3. Note that you should not click on images that ONLY have steam or any images with bad weather conditions like fogginess!
  4. Click “Start Labeling”, and then click “Continue as guest” if you don’t want to make an account to track your progress.
  5. We recommend that you go through the tutorial by pressing the “Interactive Tutorial” button. It will help you learn which videos have smoke or steam by showing you different videos.
  6. Once you think you are ready, on the “Start Labeling” page, you will 16 different video clips. Click on all of the ones where you see smoke. If you are unsure, ask someone near you for another perspective!
  7. When you are done, click “Submit and Continue”. If you want to see how many videos you identified that other people agreed with, click on “My Contribution”.
extension: Search and research the harmful oxides and gases that are being released into the atmosphere. What are they?
videodes: Get an overview of pollution and its harmful effects
video2des: Watch National Geographic's short video on air pollution

title: Adrift
summary: Oceanographers study marine microbes in the ocean, but these microbes move around, shifting around the world. In this project, you will help measure how much the ocean temperature and nitrogen levels have changed for these microbes to improve predictions for the future.
skills:
• Ecosystem dynamics, functioning, and resilience
  • Knowledge about adaptations of organisms
  • Weather and climate
instructions:
1. Go to https://adrift-project.com/ and click “Dive In”. Create an account and it will take you to a page where you can see a map.
  2. Go through the tutorial to learn about what you will be doing.
  3. Click the + button on the left side of the screen to create a simulation. Click your mouse anywhere on the map that is dark colored, meaning that it is not land. Wait about 30 seconds for the simulation to complete.
  4. The dotted lines represent the path of microbes across the ocean. Click on one of the simulation paths to log it.
  5. View the tutorial here to understand what you are logging. Magnitude refers to how high the spikes are on the graph, and frequency replies to how often the lines show up on the graph.
  6. Adjust the bars for temperature and nitrate to reflect the graph of the simulation. When you are done, click “Log Observation”.
extension: Estimate how many microbes are in the ocean. Then search it up. Were you close?

title: Snapshot Wisconsin
summary: Snapshot Wisconsin monitors wildlife using images taken from volunteers on Wisconsin’s trails. Wisconsin has 65 species of native mammals, hundreds of other species, and thousands of other plant species. Through this project, you will help monitor wildlife populations across different seasons in Wisconsin.
skills:
• Connecting and examining wildlife
  • Knowledge about growth and development of organisms
instructions:
1. Go to https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/snapshot-wisconsin and click “Get started”.
  2. Click through the tutorial.
  3. An image from a Wisconsin trail will pop up on your screen. You can click the three buttons below the image to view the images taken immediately after the first image, making it easy to see if there is motion.
  4. If you see an animal in the image, try to classify as close as possible what it is by clicking one of the 43 choices, or by using the “Looks Like”, “Body Size”, and “Coat” filters.
  5. Click on the “Field Guide” on the right side of the screen to learn more about different types of animals to help your classification.
  6. If you don’t see any animals in the screen, click “No animals present”
extension: Think of an animal, Wisconsin or other areas. How many do you think are endangered? Without using any resources, guess, then search for the answer. Were you close?
videodes: Watch a video on wildlife endagernment across the globe
video2des: Learn about wildlife in other parts of the world

title: Galaxy Zoo
summary: Galaxy Zoo is a project where students can classify galaxies by their shape. Students will be introduced to terms that describe a galaxy’s shape, as well as disturbances a galaxy may be experiencing.
people: teams of two or three students
instructions:
1. Go to this site: https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zookeeper/galaxy-zoo/classify
  2. Answer the questions, using the icons on the left of each description to help you identify each galaxy’s shape
extension: Research the different types of galaxies. Which type is your favorite?
video2des: Find out what a galaxy is

title: Chimp and See
summary: Chimp&See is a project that allows students to identify chimpanzees and the animals they interact with, helping scientists learn more about chimpanzees, and ultimately help preserve them.
people: teams of one or two students
skills:
• Animal and Habitat correlation
  • Animal and wildlife behavior
instructions:
1. Read this factsheet about each type of monkey you might see.
  2. Go to this website: https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/sassydumbledore/chimp-and-see/classify
  3. Press play on the video of the monkey.
  4. Using the factsheet, what type of animal do you think it is? Select that species on the right side. If the animal you see is not listed on the right side, or there are no animals present, select that option.
  5. Repeat steps 3-4
extension: At home or at your school, look around the building or house. Do you see any evidence that animal homes have left behind? What about bird nests, or squirrel holes? Record the location and quietly observe these areas from a distance.
videodes: Watch how animals adapt to their environment
video2des: Here's a longer video on animal building skills

title: Seabirdwatch
summary: Seabirdwatch is a project where students can identify seabirds and their behaviors, helping scientists gain more information about these birds.
people: teams of one or two students
instructions:
1. Read this factsheet about each type of bird you might see.
  2. Go to this website: https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/penguintom79/seabirdwatch/classify
  3. Select the first option on the right. Using the factsheet, click on all the birds from that species. Repeat for all the other options on the right.
  4. If you can’t see the birds well, you can either zoom in, or press the half-moon button on the bottom right of the picture. This changes the colors in the picture and makes the birds easier to see. If this doesn’t work, select the box that says, “This image is too dark/blurry to classify.”
  5. Keep classifying birds!
extension: Go outside with a piece of paper, and identify the birds you see. How many of each kind do you see?
videodes: See two seabirds battle over a piece of fish
video2des: Learn to identify different types of seabirds

title: Penguin Watch
summary: Penguin Watch is a project where students can identify penguins and their behaviors, helping scientists gain more information about penguins.
people: teams of one or two students
skills:
• Observing and understanding life cycles
  • Animal and Habitat correlation
instructions:
1. Read this factsheet about each type of penguin you might see.
  2. Go to this website: https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/penguintom79/penguin-watch/classify
  3. Select the first option on the right. Using the factsheet, click on all the penguins that match that age group. Repeat for all the other options on the right.
  4. If you can’t see the penguins well, you can zoom in. If this doesn’t work, select the box that says, “This image is too dark/blurry to classify.”
  5. Keep classifying penguins!
extension: Penguins, unlike many other mammals, have a special feature about their development that sets them apart. Look around online or ask around to find what that is - or, take a look at the videos below.
videodes: Watch a shorter video on King penguins in the arctic
video2des: Watch a longer video detailing the lives of penguis in the arctic

title: Globe Observer
summary: This citizen science project is a little unique in that its mission aligns very closely with ours. As a teacher-student initiative, it encourages teachers to lead hands-on projects with students that explores the environment around them.
instructions:
1. Download the GLOBE Observer app, and register with either you or your parent’s email address
  2. If you cannot access the app or prefer not to download it, an alternative option is to create a GLOBE web account
  3. Submit regular observations on the app or the site, which will benefit NASA’s research as well, or await teacher instruction
video2des: Here are some cool science experiments

title: Gravity Spy
summary: This citizen science project focuses on analyzing data from LIGO (Laser Interferometer Gravitational­-wave Observatory).  Despite the steady performance over several years, LIGO still experiences glitches while tracking gravitational waves, glitches which needs people to identify rather than computers.
skills:
• Recognition of patterns and repetitions
  • Paying attention to key details and instructions
instructions:
1. Visit https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy, and in the top-right corner of the website, move to “Classify”
  2. The larger image that you are looking at towards the left is the spectrogram. In this case, all it means is it is a picture of the glitch
  3. On the right-hand side, you can see three different types of glitches it can be - a “Blip”, “Whistle”, and “None/Other”
  4. Choose one of the options that best describes what the glitch on the left looks like
  5. A Blip tends to look very sharp, a single large point on the picture
  6. A Whistle looks like an outline of a curve
  7. “None” or “Other” are any other types of shape that looks very different
  8. Once you have made your selection, click “Done” and you will move on to another image
extension: Research about gravity! Why does it cause objects to fall? Try dropping a heavier object (like your lunchbox) and a lighter object (like your pencil). Which one do you think will fall first? What actually happens? Who discovered gravity?
videodes: Learn about the rule that dominates all - Gravity!
video2des: Take a look into our Unvierse and the Solar System we live in

title: Invader ID
summary: This citizen science project helps identify different types of organisms that have been left to grow across various surface tiles. Through identification and tracking of these species, we are able to learn how they grow and what their growth means for the changing coastal areas.
instructions:
1. Go to https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/serc/invader-id
  2. When you access the site and move to the top-right area, there should be a “classify” tab that you should click on
  3. Once there, you will see an image on the left-hand side. There will be a black circle on the picture that should be the area you are focusing on
  4. To the right are a series of options and category of organisms. Select as many organisms as you see in the black ring, but look through the example organisms that appear before submitting your answers
  5. You can also hover right above the categories and “filter” different appearance types if you are having trouble finding the shape or pattern
  6. If the area appears the same as the surface around it, it may be possible there are no organisms in the picture. In this case, click on “Nothing There”
extension: Funny enough, there are many creatures that are marine invertebrates, but we never hear about them. Did you know that Patrick the star is a marine invertebrate? Research different types of marine invertebrates and make a list of your top three favorites to share with your teacher.
videodes: Watch this video to get an introduction to marine invertebrates!
video2des: Learn about the difference between vertebrates and invertebrates

title: Floating Forests
summary: The Floating Forest project helps analyze kelp in collected imagery. The Landsat series of satellites have been collecting images of the surface of the earth since 1984. However, it was difficult to identify kelp in the pictures with computers since they are unable to separate greens, which is why human eyes are needed to achieve this task.
instructions:
1. Go to https://www.floatingforests.org/
  2. Once you access the site, move to the top right-hand corner and click on “Classify”
  3. Once you get there, there will be a tutorial explaining how to identify the lep patches. Here is a brief(er) explanation:
  4. Using your mousepad, zoom in on the large picture on the left-hand side and trace around, or outline, the individual kelp patches with your mouse (which will be in bright green)
  5. Kelp patches will typically be surrounded by the dark-colored water and around the larger and light green land-masses
  6. If you make a mistake, let go of the mouse and click on the “x” that appears over the kelp patch
  7. Once you are done tracing all the individual kep patches, confirm your work and click on “Next” to move on to the next image
  8. If you see no kelp patches, click on the option that says “All Land” if you are sure
extension: Research the different types of kelp! Which one is your favorite? Why is it your favorite? Share out in small groups about the different kinds of kelp and their strengths and weaknesses.
videodes: Explore a kelp forest and California!
video2des: Check out this new sustainable food trend! Learn about kelp pickles
